question: Jamal Malik.
answer: So, Jamal, tell us a bit about yourself. A Phone-basher! And what type of call centre would this be?

question: XL 5. Mobile phones.
answer: Aha! So, you're the man who rings me up every single day of my life with Special Offers, huh?

question: No, actually, I'm an assistant.
answer: An Assistant Phone-basher? And what does an Assistant Phone- basher do, exactly?

question: I- I get tea for people and-
answer: - a chi-wallah! Why didn't you say? So, ladies and gentlemen, Jamal Malik from Mumbai, let's play Who Wants To Be A Millionaire...!

question: Has he confessed, yet?
answer: Apart from his name, I can't get a word out of the runt.

question: You've been here all bloody night, Srinivas. What have you been doing?

A little electricity will loosen his tongue. Every night I get home, "why can't we have a/c like Bajan Chacha? Why don't you care about your poor family, dying in this heat." Twenty-four years a policeman and I can't afford bloody a/c. But you. You've got ten million rupees ek dum guaranteed, yaar? And who knows how much further? Fancy the twenty million, do you? I think you probably do. So. Were you wired up? A mobile or a pager, correct? Some little hidden gadget? No? A coughing accomplice in the audience? Microchip under the skin, huh? Srinivas! Look, it's hot, my wife is giving me hell, I've got a desk full of murderers, rapists, extortionists, assorted bum-bandits...and you. Why don't you save us both a lot of time? Hmm?
Ar wa, Srinivas, we'll have Amnesty International in here next, peeing their pants about human rights. Get him down, tidy him up, for God's sake.
answer: Maybe he did know the answers.

question: Inspector. How good to meet you. Clearly the kid cheated.
So, it is just a question of how, no?
answer: Indeed, Sir. The proof. That is all we need.

question: We are lucky to have a man of your obvious experience on the case. This kid might run rings around us filmi types, but he won't make fools out of the Mumbai Police Force, I can see that. In front of sixty million people. Which is what will happen if we don't get a result, Gentlemen. He goes back on the show to rob us all with the whole of India watching. But. I can rely on you. Has he- has he made any allegations?
He's a cunning one. A convincing liar. Don't be taken in, Inspector, don't be taken in.
answer: So, Mister Malik, the man who knows the answers. Talk.

question: So, are you ready for your first question for one thousand rupees?
Not bad money to sit in a chair and answer a question. Better than making the tea, no?
Like I said. He's the most famous man in India...!
answer: ...A) The truth alone triumphs. B) Lies alone triumph. C) Fashion alone triumphs. D) Money alone triumphs. What do we think, Jamal? The most famous phrase in our country's history. Maybe you want to phone a friend? Or Ask the Audience? I have a hunch they might just know the answer. What do we think?

question: Yes.
Ask the audience.
answer: Well, you're the contestant, Jamal. Put the poor man out of his misery, Ladies and Gentlemen. Press your key-pad now.

question: Wrong. Fifteen since Divali. Who stole Constable Varma's bicycle outside Dadar Station last Thursday?
Everyone in Juhu knows that. Even five year-olds.
answer: I'll give you five hundred rupees if you just admit it. You go home, I go home. Everybody happy. No, you want to go back on the programme and win twenty million rupees, don't you?

question: Salim! Mister Nandha.
answer: Ram nam satya hai, Babri Masjid dhvasth hai.

question: Mister Nandha?
answer: We have destroyed your mosque. Now, the followers of Ram will drive you dogs out of our city. Ram has returned to his temple! Ram has returned!

question: Let's go, bhai. We should go back. See if Ama- What about Jeevan Chacha? Maybe he-
answer: - I saw him. He was with them.

question: But he wouldn't hurt-
But-
answer: - shut up, Jamal, can't you? Just shut up! Ja!

question: What shall we do?
answer: Go away. Ja, ja! She'll have the Security Guard onto us, standing there.

question: Not if we let her in.
She could be the third musketeer.
answer: I am the head of this family, now. And I say no. Piss off, you. We don't even know what the third musketeer's called.

question: I wake up every morning wishing I didn't know the answer to that question? If it wasn't for Ram and Allah, I would still have a Mother. D) A bow and arrow.
Final answer.
answer: Computer-ji, D lock kiya-jaye. Jamal Malik, you answered D? Ram is depicted with a bow and arrow in his hand. And guess what? You've just won sixteen thousand rupees! Well done, my friend. Time for a commercial break- don't go away, now. Got lucky, huh? I'd take the money. You'll never get the next one.

question: You're from the Juhu slum, aren't you?
answer: Hmm? Sure. Know where I live now, kid? Pali Hill. Twelve bedrooms, a/c in every room, two kitchens, a gym and a screening room. Steel balls is what it takes, my friend, steel balls. We're having fun here. They love it...Where the hell do you get them from?

question: Stop wetting your pants. I'll be a good little boy with the next one. Promise. Meet me after the show. Please.
Nita, I can explain.
answer: No need. I read it in bloody Stardust. Didn't even have the balls to tell me. "Prem's happiness with another baby on the way". After everything you said...

question: Baby, it all happened before I met you. I swear to you.
answer: She's got the gestation period of an elephant, then.

question: You see? Amidst all this misery, only you can make me laugh.
Steel balls. Okay, Juhu boy, you've had a good run. Take your Mother to Khandala and eat some chiki.
Well, your girlfriend then. Even better.
Welcome back to Who Wants to be a Millionaire! Our contestant, Jamal Malik, Call Centre Assistant- from Mumbai, is on sixteen thousand rupees and has already used one lifeline

Then, let's play. For sixty-four thousand rupees. The British architect Frederick Stevens designed which famous building in India? Is it So, what's it to be? Walk away and this cheque for sixteen thousand rupees is yours. Look, it's even got your name on it.
answer: I don't have a bank account. But I'll take cash.

question: Nope. Looks like the Producer's stolen my wallet again-
You'll play?
Well, well, well. We've got a wild one, here. For sixty-four thousand rupees, Ladies and Gentlemen, the question once again....
answer: Latika! Latika! Latika! Latika! Yes. Final answer. Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus.

question: And did she come back?
answer: I wouldn't be here if she had.

question: Pretty was she? Guess not.
answer: The most beautiful woman in the world.

question: That's the chutiy out the way. Now, man to man. How did you know all the answers?
answer: If I knew, I'd tell you.

question: If I knew, I'd tell you.
answer: Now we're into the serious money. For two hundred and fifty thousand rupees, ladies and gentlemen, a quarter of a million rupees...the song Chalo Ri Murali was written by which famous Indian poet. Was it A) Surdas. B) Tulsidas. C) Mira Bai. D) Kabir. Remember you still have two lifelines- fifty- fifty and Phone A Friend. Tempted to use one?

question: No.
I know this one.
answer: Oh. I see. An expert on the poets, huh?

question: Okay. Take him out the back. Now the other one. Salim, go get Jamal.

Gunfighter Number One, isn't that right, Salim? The money, the women, the cars...you want them bad, huh? And why not? The time has come to choose, yaar. The life of a slum dog or the life of a man. A real man. A gunfighter, Salim. Your destiny is in your hands, bhai. You can be me. Or nobody. Understand?
...weddings, government things, big parties. If Maman says my voice is ready. Big money.
Easily. Maybe an apartment.
That's what Arvind said. On Harbour Road. You, me and Salim. The three musketeers.
answer: Harbour Road! We can have ice cream from Babanji's.

question: Every day if we want. It's my turn.
Jamal, hello. You have done well. It's time for you to- turn professional.
Sing me a song, yaar. How about Chalo Ri Murali, huh? My favourite.
What?
answer: I've turned professional. What can I do?

question: The question was, for two hundred and fifty thousand rupees
Surdas. Apka final jawab?
Computer-ji, A lock kiya-jaye. Guess what? You're right.
answer: Blind singers earn double. You know that.

question: They had other plans. Though it took me a long, long time to find out.
Where you going?
Salim? Is this heaven?
So what's that?
Some hotel, huh?
answer: Please, what time is the next tour?

question: Err- No, I-
answer: - we're on a very tight schedule, you see, young man. Have to see the Red Fort this afternoon. Would it be possible to show us around now? Obviously we understand it would cost more for just the two of us...

question: But of course, Madam. Please follow me. This is....the Taj Mahal. The Taj Mahal was built by the Emperor Khurram for his wife Mumtaz who was maximum beautiful woman in the whole world. When she died, the Emperor decided to build this five star hotel for everyone who wanted to visit her tomb...but he died in- in fifteen eighty-seven, before any of the rooms were built. Or the lifts. The swimming pool, however, as you can see was completed on schedule in top class fashion.
answer: It says nothing of this in the guide book.

question: With respect, Madam, the guide book is written by a bunch of lazy, good-for-nothing, Indian beggars.
And this, Lady and Gentleman, is burial place of Mumtaz.
A road traffic accident.
Maximum pile-up. Exactly, Sir. She was on the way to the hospital when it happened.
answer: You've seen the way they drive around here...

question: You wanted to see the `real India', Mister David. Here it is.
answer: Why don't you put it back and listen to the music? It's called Orfeo. Orpheus and Eurydice. Orpheus- that one there- is looking for his lover, Eurydice. She died, but he can't live without her. The pain is so bad that he goes to the underworld- the place we go when we die- to try to get her back.

question: You can't do that. Can you?
Does he find her?
Woah! What are you- Jamal?
Go? Go where?
Don't be stupid. We're making good money here.
answer: We should have gone a long time ago.

question: Oh, God. Baby brother's in love. With a flat-chested hijra.
answer: Latika was one of us. A musketeer.

question: A musketeer...Grow up, Jamal. Look, how was I to know they'd beat you up. Here, you can have some of the cash. Come on...
How much?
Get a lot of hundred dollar bills in your line of work, Jamal?
answer: The minimum tip for my services.

question: Now I know why my cell phone bill is so high...they pay the chi-wallah in hundred dollar bills!
Woah! We haven't locked the computer, man. You're going to play?
answer: I think I just have. Haven't I?

question: You certainly have. C. Right?
Not confusing your Franklins? Benjamin for Roosevelt?
answer: I've never heard of Roosevelt Franklin.

question: Who's on the thousand rupee note?
It's Gandhi!
Don't get clever or I'll get the electricity out again.
answer: They didn't ask me that question. I don't know why. Ask them.

question: Room service, good afternoon?... Yes, sir. Two chicken burgers, two fries, one cocoa-cola and one mango lassi and a large bottle of mineral water...Bisleri or Himalayan Spring, Sir?...Certainly, Sir. That will be with you in fifteen minutes, Sir. Thank you. Have a nice day. Two chicken burgers, coke, mango lassi and a bottle of Bisleri. I'm going to Chowpatti again, okay? Want to come?
answer: For God's sake. You got some disease? You force me back to this shit-hole, we leave our friends, a good life, loads of money- for this. Isn't that enough?

question: We came back to find her.
answer: No, you did, Jamal, not me. Me, I don't give a shit about her. Plenty of pussy in Bombay for Salim. Oh, yes, sir! You should come down the Cages on Saturday night instead of searching for your lost love.

question: I'm going to Chowpatti.
answer: "I'm going to Chowpatti". There are nineteen million people in this city, Jamal. Forget her. She's history.

question: Namaste, Sahib. Any kindness you give will be repaid in heaven many times. A fifty. And a hundred! Blessings upon you, Sahib.
There are many ways of seeing.
Dollars. But how many?
Now you are playing with me, Sahib.
What is on it? The pictures. Tell me.
answer: A building. With a clock on it. Trees behind it.

question: The other side. Turn it over.
answer: A man- it doesn't say his name. He is sort of bald, but has long hair on the sides.

question: Benjamin Franklin. My God, my God. Thank you, Sahib. You were generous the first time. But this... And without even a song? So you are rich, now, are you, Jamal? I am happy for you.
You got away. I didn't. That is all. No, no tears. Tears mock me all the more.
- how's your voice, Jamal?
answer: I don't know. I haven't sung since- since then. Arvind, I-

question: - and your eyes?
answer: My eyes? My eyes are fine.

question: Then stay away, chutiy, and count your blessings every morning you open them and see the sun rising. You owe Maman. He doesn't forget.
answer: I owe Latika. Please. Is she alive? Arvind, is she alive?

question: Alive? Oh, she's alive alright. It's your life, Jamal. Pila Street. They call her Cherry, now.

Look who we have here, Punnoose. Hello again, Jamal. Salim. Never forget a face. Especially one that I own. Whatever you like. Have fun. Just make sure that you dispose of them properly afterwards. No traces, thank you. You really thought you could just walk in and take my prize away? Have you any idea how much this little virgin is worth, bhen chod? Get them out of here. Please continue, Master-ji.
answer: No. Leave him. Get over there.

question: Let's not be foolish, Salim. Heavy, aren't they?
You can have money. Here. Take it. Go. Disappear with your friend and we'll forget all about this. Okay?
answer: Maman never forgets. Isn't that right?

question: Oh, Maman can make an exception.
answer: Can't take that risk, Maman. Sorry. Safety catch. Come on.

question: We should be celebrating.
He was going to kill us.
answer: Where did you get the gun?

question: What? Typical. I save your life and you're on at me. All you ever do is mess us up. Whenever you're around-
answer: - shut up, can't you? Just shut up.

question: Why can't you just be happy, huh?
Latika? Salim?
307 here. I want a bottle of Johnny Walker Red Label, beer, wine-
Ah! Chicken.... What kind of chicken?
- aloo gobi, rice- Pop Tarts!
answer: Hold the line, chutiye. Pop Tarts?

question: On the tv. The commercial. Everybody's happy when they have Pop Tarts.
answer: Exactly! A bucket of Pop Tarts, chutiye. Found some lunghi! Atcha, atcha. I'm not! Where's Salim?

question: Maman's gang will hunt us. You know that?
Me neither.
answer: That dance you were doing. In Pila Street. Show me.

question: You came back for me.
Hey.
Come.
answer: No. Salim....Bhai, you've had a lot to drink...

question: I am the elder. And I am the boss. For once, you do as I say.
- chup, sali. I am Number One now!
Get yourself a room, bhai. The man with the Colt 45 says chup.
Rajneesh... - `friends and family'. I know. Two minutes.
answer: ...if you want a chance to be a contestant on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, dial the number now.

question: You have to dial when Prem says "if". "If you want the chance to be a contestant on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire..." That's when they open the lines. That's what Anjum in Technical says. He put the system in. Hello, Mrs... ...Mackintosh from King Gussie. Kinoosie? - just down the road from your house, Mrs Mackintosh. Next to the loch. Loch Big- Loch Ben. Next door to Detective Taggart's flat. Indeed yes, Mrs Mackintosh. I have to wade through a metre of water every morning. Yes, yes, Mrs Mackintosh. In my kilt. It's alright once I've had my porridge, my haggis and a few Scotch whiskies- and the monsoon's nearly over, so- I don't think that's a good idea. He is a very important man, Mrs Mackintosh- - and he doesn't like bloody time wasters. Salim? I am calling from XL 5 Communications Sir. As a valued customer, we are offering you a free upgrade with our `friends and- Family. Hello, Salim.
No.
No. And I've never been to UK before. But I'll still have a go. Why not?
answer: Can someone call me an ambulance?

question: I can't remember.
answer: You can't remember. Does that mean you did know? Once?

question: I don't think it's Oxford.
answer: Based on your extensive travelling, right?

question: Well, Oxford has Broad Street, Saint Aldates, Turl Street, Queen Street, The High and Magdalene Bridge- which is pronounced Maudlin, so-
answer: I thought you hadn't been to UK.

question: Oh, I haven't. And it's not Leeds, because that's Elland Road, Kirkgate Market, Commercial Street, St Peter's-
answer: - what might it be then, Jamal?

question: Well, I don't think it's Cambridge.
answer: Cambridge Circus is not in Cambridge? Dare I ask why?

question: Too obvious. There's definitely an Oxford Circus in London, and there's a rowing race between Oxford and Cambridge so there's probably a Cambridge Circus too. I'll go for D) London.
answer: That's the logic that's got him this far, Ladies and Gentlemen. Who are we to argue? So. Jamal. D. Apka final jawab?

question: If the Gods are with me...Final answer. D.
answer: Computer-ji, D lock kiya-jaye. It's been a rollercoaster ride all the way, a pleasure to have you on the show, my friend, but I'm sorry to say that you're....incredibly, absolutely right! Ladies and Gentlemen, Jamal Malik, the man with two and a half million rupees! A few hours ago, you were fetching tea for the phone- wallahs. Now you are richer than they ever will ever be. What a player, Ladies and Gentleman! What a player. For five million rupees, my friend

question: A). Samuel Colt.
answer: A). Samuel Colt. Are you sure? Final answer?

question: Final answer.
answer: You had two and a half million rupees. If I may-? Ladies and Gentlemen, the chi- wallah has done it again! D. Is right! Incredible!

question: What sports do you play?

None. Oh, dear, oh dear, oh dear. Not to worry, there's only ten million rupees at stake... Which cricketer has scored the most first class centuries in history. Was it A) Sachin Tendulkar, B) Ricky Ponting, C) Michael Slater, D) Jack Hobbs. You've got a cheque for five million rupees in your hands. You've still got two life-lines, Phone A Friend and 50/50. For ten million rupees Are you sure you want to do this?
Jamal! God is good, bhai. God is good. Maman's boys were after us. Had to skip.
Left a message at reception. Waited weeks for you in Nagpur.
answer: There was no message at reception.

question: Bhai, I left a message.

I know. Can you believe it? This was our slum. We lived just there, huh? Now it is business, apartments, call centres...Fuck USA, fuck China. India is at the centre of the world, now, bhai. And I am at the centre of the centre, Jamal. This is all Javed-bhai's.
answer: Javed Mehta? The Gangster from our slum? You work for him?

question: Who else would protect us from Maman's gang, huh?
answer: What do you do for him?

question: Anything he asks. He is coming. You must go. My card.
You think I am going to let you out of my sight again, little brother? You stay with me now. Ab phut!
Still? She's gone, Jamal. Long gone. Now go. Quick. Look at it, bhai, look at it! A khuda mujh baksh d main bahut gunaah kiy hain....
answer: Baba, I am the new cook from the agency. A thousand apologies, I am late for the Memsaab.

question: Baba, I am your dishwasher!
answer: Haven't I told you, don't interrupt when I'm watching- - come inside. I'll show you the kitchen. Jamal, Jamal, look at you...! Ar wa, Jamal....

question: You've hurt your eye.
To see you.
Why does everyone love this programme?
answer: It's the chance to escape, isn't it? Walk into another life. Doesn't everyone want that?

question: You have another life. A rich one.
answer: Who'd have thought it possible? A slum dog, with all this.

question: Are you happy?
answer: I have five star food, five star clothes. I sleep in a bed, not on the street. From where we come from, Jamal, that is happiness.

question: You don't look so happy with a black eye.
answer: You turn up here out of nowhere, telling me I'm not happy God, Javed will kill you. Here.

question: Love. That will feed us, will it?
answer: It won't buy you a new dishwasher, but it might make you happy.

question: Where have you been? Get in the real world, Jamal.
answer: You and me. That is the real world. Come away with me.

question: You're crazy.
Salim? You still believe in Salim? Jamal...I'll be gone soon, anyway. Bombay's got too dangerous for-
You think he'd tell me?
answer: Straight bat, straight bat, dammit. No! A single! No, no, no! stupid ben chod idiot... And what is this shit supposed to be, mader chod? Get out. Get out!

question: Now go, before he kills us both.
answer: Latika, where's my bloody shirt? The Armani.

question: Coming! You want to do something for me?
Then forget me.
answer: I'll wait at VT station. Five o'clock every day until you come. I love you.

question: Why can't you let it alone? You want money, I'll give you money. Girls? I can get you girls.
You're like some crazy man- you're obsessed.
Know what your destiny is, crazy boy? A bullet between the eyes. And after that, he'll kill her. Is that what you want? Huh?
answer: Me, I don't care. Latika? She's already half dead.

question: Yes. About that, you are right.

Time for a commercial break, Ladies and Gentlemen. I know, I know, I can't stand the tension either. Don't even think about leaving your seat. We'll be back. You've got the luck of the devil, yaar, I'll give you that.

Oh, the toilet. Sure. Naveed, Jamal wants the bog. A guy from the slums becomes a millionaire overnight. You know the only other person who's done that? Me. I know what it's like. I know what you've been through. You've said that before, yaar. What? You can't take the money and run now. You're on the edge of history, kid! Maybe it is written, my friend. You're going to win this. Trust me, you're going to win.
answer: Latika! Latika! Latika! Latika! Latika! Latika! Latika! Salim!

question: Do the right thing and in approximately three minutes you will be as famous as me. And as rich as me. Almost. From rags to Raja. It's your destiny. Welcome back to Who Wants to Be A Millionaire? In the chair tonight is Jamal Malik- as if we don't know! In an amazing run, Jamal has already five million rupees but, not content with that, has chosen to gamble for one Crore- that's ten million million rupees. What a player! The question one more time
answer: I know it isn't Sachin Tendulkar.

question: That's a start. So, it could be Ricky Ponting, Jack Hobbs or Michael Slater.
answer: I'll use a life-line. Fifty- fifty.

question: Okay. Computer, take away two wrong answers. Well, you were right about Sachin Tendulkar. The computer has taken away A) Sachin Tendulkar and C) Michael Slater. That leaves you a fifty-fifty choice, Jamal. B) Ricky Ponting or D) Jack Hobbs. What do you think? Decision time. For half a million rupees. Your answer You sure? Not B) Ricky Ponting? The Australian? Great cricketer.
Do you know? So it could be B, Ricky Ponting?
Final Answer?

Computer-ji D lock kiya-jaye. With one hundred and ninety- seven first class centuries, the answer is...D. Jack Hobbs! Jamal Malik, Crorepati! I cannot believe what I am seeing here, tonight, Ladies and Gentlemen....So, are you ready for the final question for two Crore rupees- twenty million rupees?
answer: Not really, but...maybe it is written, no?

question: Maybe, indeed. Okay, okay. For twenty million rupees, the final question on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? Ohhhhh! Just when I thought I would need a pacemaker fitted, we're out of time! What a show, Ladies and Gentlemen, what a show. Join us tomorrow night to see if Jamal Malik has made the biggest mistake of his life or has just won the biggest prize in the history of Indian television....Same place, same time. You wouldn't dare miss it. Goodnight!
Latika!
Where? Where is she?
Where?
answer: I don't know! Wouldn't say, would they? They had to get out fast. The police. Honestly.

question: This way, Jamal, this way. Great show, my friend. See you tomorrow, huh?
He's a cheat.
answer: This was you? You called them? How d'you know he's cheating?

question: Oh, come on! Of course he is. He's a bloody village boy. Even when I fed him the wrong answer the little shit got it right.
But you Thank you, Constable. All that remains is to work out whether it was manslaughter or murder. Ten years, or life.
answer: So? Have you charged him yet?

question: I- progress is being made sir.
No, Sir.
answer: And if that isn't enough for you...

question: That's-?
answer: - yes, yes! The boy's a bloody hero with every beggar and thief in the city. We're in danger of looking very stupid, here, Inspector.

question: Whilst I'm not convinced he actually cheated, I have got-
answer: - Prem Kumar himself- a man of great standing and integrity- said the kid was a liar and a cheat. What more do you need?

question: We're out. I'll just get- Syed. Final answer? That boy. He will never give up. Never. Crazy chutiy. Ja. Go.
- just drive. There won't be another chance. Go.
It is not written.
Good luck.
answer: Hey. Sweetheart. What about me? I'm sweating, here.

question: You should be.
Not if you were the only man in the world.
answer: But I am the only man in the world.

question: Welcome back to Who Wants to be a Millionaire? I can safely say that tonight is the biggest night of both of our lives, Ladies and Gentlemen. Jamal Malik, the Call Centre worker from Mumbai has already won one Crore rupees, a cool ten million. Tonight, he can walk away with that in his pocket or make the biggest gamble in television history and go for the final question and a staggering twenty million rupees! Jamal, are you ready for that question?
Big reader, are you Jamal? A lover of literature?

Lucky! In Alexandre Dumas' book, The Three Musketeers, two of the musketeers are called Athos and Porthos. What was the name of the third musketeer. Was it A) Aramis, B) Cardinal Richelieu, C) D'Artagnan, D) Planchet. The final question, for twenty million rupees
answer: Would you believe it? I don't.

question: You don't? So, you're going to take the ten million and walk?
No?
You just said you don't know the answer. I heard that, right? You do understand that if you get the answer wrong, you lose everything? Ten million rupees. A fortune, Jamal.
answer: I'd like to phone a friend.

question: We're going to the wire, Ladies and Gentlemen, we are going to the wire. The final Life-line. Here we go.... It's ringing. Doesn't look as if your friend is in, Jamal. Who is it?
- the sort of brother who'd go for a walk on the twenty million rupee question?
answer: It's the only number I know.

question: Okay! So, Latika, you want to hear the question one more time? And let's be clear about this. Twenty million rupees ride on your answer. You have thirty seconds. Jamal, please read out the question to Latika.
The question, Jamal.
answer: In Alexandre Dumas' book, The Three Musketeers, two of the musketeers are called Athos and Porthos. What was the name of the third musketeer. Was it A) Aramis, B) Cardinal Richelieu, C) D'Artagnan, D) Planchet.

question: Fifteen seconds.
Ten seconds. So, Latika, what do you think? Five, four, three, two, one. Time's up! Your answer. Oh... You really are on your own, now, Jamal. Your answer A. Because?
Apka final jawab?

Computer-ji A lock kiya-jaye. Jamal Malik, Call Centre Assistant from Mumbai, for two Crore, twenty million rupees, you were asked who the Third Musketeer was in the novel by Alexandre Dumas. You used your final life-line to phone a friend. You answered A. Aramis.....which is...I have to tell you...the correct answer! Ladies and Gentlemen, Jamal Malik, Crorepati! What a night! We have all been present at the making of history, Ladies and Gentlemen! Jamal Malik, millionaire!
